title: John Bercow in row over 'bullying stitch-up' as victims say new complaints system is 'too late'
text:
Senior officials who accused John Bercow of bullying are boycotting Parliament's new complaints process over claims an "establishment stitch-up" has shielded the Speaker from being investigated before he steps down this week.

David Leakey, the former Black Rod, and Angus Sinclair, the Speaker's former private secretary, said a new rule allowing investigations into grievance claims by ex staff has come "too late" - just days before Mr Bercow is due to leave office on Thursday after more than a decade.

In an interview with The Telegraph, Mr Sinclair, who broke a non-disclosure agreement to speak out about alleged bullying by Mr Bercow last year, said: "The horse has long bolted."
